I started attending the meetings, held in secret in the back rooms of pubs and the dimly lit basements of houses. I listened to the passionate speeches, the desperate pleas for justice. I saw the faces of the men—worn, weary, but filled with a fierce determination. And then I met Sarah. She wasn’t like Elara. Sarah was fire and steel, a whirlwind of energy and conviction. She worked in the textile mills, a place even more brutal than the ironworks. She organized the women, taught them to read and write, and rallied them to demand better conditions. She spoke with a clarity and force that captivated me.

text: We bonded over shared ideals, over the belief that things could—and *should*—be different. We spent hours discussing politics, economics, the future of New Birmingham. She challenged my complacency, my cynicism. She made me feel alive again. Our courtship wasn’t filled with romantic walks or whispered promises. It was forged in the heat of the struggle, in the shared risk of fighting for a better world. It was practical, grounded, and deeply meaningful. We married in a small ceremony, attended by a handful of friends and fellow activists. No fancy dresses, no elaborate feast. Just a simple exchange of vows and a shared commitment to building a life based on justice and equality. The strike intensified. The owners brought in scabs, men desperate enough to work for any wage. Violence erupted. The streets of New Birmingham became a battleground. I found myself on the picket lines, facing down angry workers and brutal police. Sarah was arrested, accused of inciting unrest. I spent days frantically trying to secure her release, pleading with lawyers and politicians, raising money for her defense. It was a terrifying time, but it also solidified our bond. We were in this together, fighting for something bigger than ourselves.
